sections.heading: Greetings
sections.content:
Greetings in Japanese are situation-specific and reflect social relationships. Unlike English where "hello" works anytime, Japanese has distinct greetings for different times of day, contexts, and relationships.

English: "Hello" (all-purpose) Japanese: Multiple greetings Time-specific Context-dependent Relationship-aware Choose appropriately

children.heading: Morning greeting
children.content: おはよう "Good morning" (casual) おはようございます "Good morning" (polite) Use: Until about 10-11 AM Common: Everywhere First greeting of day Casual with friends/family Polite at work/strangers

children.heading: Daytime greeting
children.content: こんにちは "Good afternoon / Hello" Use: From ~11 AM to sunset Common: General greeting Less formal than おはよう One politeness level Works broadly

children.heading: Evening greeting
children.content: こんばんは "Good evening" Use: After sunset (~6 PM onward) Common: Evening encounters Formal enough for any setting Not for close friends More polite than casual

children.heading: Night farewell (not greeting)
children.content: おやすみ "Good night" (casual) おやすみなさい "Good night" (polite) Use: When going to bed Not: For evening meetings Specifically for sleeping Farewell, not greeting

children.heading: Arriving at work
children.content: おはようございます "Good morning" Use: Regardless of actual time Common: Work culture Shows respect Said to everyone Even at night shifts Work-specific custom

children.heading: During work
children.content: お疲れ様です "Thank you for your hard work" Use: Passing colleagues Common: Throughout day Multipurpose greeting Shows acknowledgment Workplace standard Not outside work

children.heading: Leaving work
children.content: お疲れ様でした "Thank you for your work today" お先に失礼します "Excuse me for leaving first" Use: When departing Response: お疲れ様でした Common courtesy Respectful departure Daily ritual

children.heading: First meeting
children.content: 初めまして "Nice to meet you (for the first time)" はじめまして、[name]です "Nice to meet you, I'm [name]" よろしくお願いします "Please treat me kindly / Look forward to working with you" Formal introduction Shows respect Standard sequence

children.heading: Subsequent meetings
children.content: お久しぶりです "Long time no see" (polite) 久しぶり "Long time no see" (casual) また会えて嬉しいです "I'm happy to see you again" Acknowledging gap Friendly reconnection

children.heading: Meeting expectations
children.content: お会いできて光栄です "It's an honor to meet you" お会いできて嬉しいです "I'm happy to meet you" Use: Important people Use: Genuine happiness Shows appreciation More emotional Personal connection

children.heading: Coming home
children.content: ただいま "I'm home" Use: Entering your home Response: おかえり/おかえりなさい Family ritual Casual announcement Expected phrase Cultural practice

children.heading: Welcoming home
children.content: おかえり "Welcome home" (casual) おかえりなさい "Welcome home" (polite) Response: ただいま Use: To family members Warm greeting Shows care Daily exchange

children.heading: Entering someone's home
children.content: お邪魔します "Excuse me for disturbing" Use: Entering someone's home Literal: "I will be a bother" Shows humility Standard phrase Cultural politeness Always say this

children.heading: Leaving someone's home
children.content: お邪魔しました "Thank you for having me / Sorry for the intrusion" Use: Departing from home Past tense of entering phrase Gratitude expressed Polite closure Shows appreciation

children.heading: Answering phone
children.content: もしもし "Hello" (phone only) はい、[name]です "Yes, this is [name]" Business: お電話ありがとうございます "Thank you for calling" Phone-specific Never in person Cultural norm

children.heading: Making a call
children.content: もしもし "Hello" [name]ですが "This is [name], but..." お忙しいところすみません "Sorry to bother you when you're busy" Polite opening Identifies self Shows consideration

children.heading: Among friends
children.content: やあ / やっほー "Hey / Hi" よう "Yo" おっす "Sup" 元気？ "How are you?" Very casual Young people Friends only

children.heading: Slang greetings
children.content: ちーす "Hey" (from こんにちは) おは "Morning" (from おはよう) Use: Very casual Friends/peers only Not appropriate formally Shortened forms Youth language

children.heading: Physical greeting
children.content: Slight bow: Casual greeting Medium bow: Standard greeting Deep bow: Formal/respectful greeting Bow while saying greeting Eye contact varies Depth shows respect Physical component Cultural expectation

children.heading: New Year
children.content: あけましておめでとうございます "Happy New Year" 今年もよろしくお願いします "Please treat me well this year too" Use: First days of January Very important Specific to New Year Major cultural event

children.heading: Seasonal greetings
children.content: 暑中お見舞い申し上げます "Mid-summer greetings" 寒中お見舞い申し上げます "Mid-winter greetings" Written greetings Formal cards Seasonal awareness Traditional practice

children.heading: Store staff to customers
children.content: いらっしゃいませ "Welcome" Use: Customer entering No response expected Standard retail Automatic greeting Shows hospitality

children.heading: Servers and staff
children.content: いらっしゃいませ "Welcome" お待たせいたしました "Thank you for waiting" May I help you? Standard service phrases Professional greeting

children.heading: Kansai region
children.content: まいど "Hello / Thanks" (business) Use: Osaka area Merchants especially Local flavor Regional identity Friendly tone

children.heading: Other variations
children.content: Standard: こんにちは Casual male: よう Casual female: やっほー Regional accents Gender patterns Style differences

children.heading: Common sequences
children.content: おはようございます。今日もいい天気ですね。 "Good morning. Nice weather today too." こんにちは。お元気ですか。 "Hello. How are you?" Greeting + small talk Natural flow Social lubrication

children.heading: Text/chat greetings
children.content: おつ "Good work" (shortened) よろ "Please" (shortened) w (笑) "Lol" Modern communication Very casual Internet culture

children.heading: Email openings
children.content: お世話になっております "Thank you for your continued support" Use: Business emails Standard opening Shows relationship Professional norm Not personal emails

children.heading: Business meetings
children.content: 本日はお時間をいただき、ありがとうございます "Thank you for your time today" お忙しいところ恐れ入ります "I'm sorry to take your time when you're busy" Respectful language Shows gratitude Professional setting Keigo required Standard phrases

children.heading: Teachers and students
children.content: Student arriving: おはようございます、先生 "Good morning, teacher" Teacher: おはよう "Good morning" Class beginning: お願いします Class ending: ありがとうございました Educational setting Respectful hierarchy Daily routine

children.heading: Passing neighbors
children.content: おはようございます "Good morning" 行ってきます "I'm heading out" 行ってらっしゃい "Take care / Have a good one" Community connection Daily interaction Social fabric

children.heading: Situations to avoid
children.content: Don't greet: - Every time passing same person - In quiet places (libraries) - When someone is clearly busy - On trains (strangers) Read the situation Context matters

children.heading: When response needed
children.content: おはようございます → おはようございます こんにちは → こんにちは お疲れ様です → お疲れ様です Mirror the greeting Same politeness level Acknowledge properly

children.heading: When no response
children.content: いらっしゃいませ → (no response) "Welcome" at stores No response needed Staff to customer One-way greeting

children.heading: Choosing the right level
children.content: Family/close friends: Casual forms Colleagues: Polite forms Customers/superiors: Very polite forms Context determines choice Relationship matters When in doubt, more polite

children.heading: Errors to avoid
children.content: ❌ こんにちは in morning ✓ おはようございます ❌ おやすみ as evening greeting ✓ こんばんは ❌ Greeting every time you pass someone ✓ Once per day is enough Learn proper usage Avoid awkwardness

children.heading: Real conversation
children.content: A: おはようございます B: あ、おはようございます。今日は寒いですね A: 本当に。気をつけてくださいね B: はい、ありがとうございます Greeting + small talk Natural progression Building rapport
